text:
I ask this question to everyone,
I'm going to ask you as well.
What got you into STEM?

I have always been such a curious person.
When I was in year three at school,

my teacher actually said to my parents,
"Vanessa asks too many questions".
Like that is a bad thing!

That is the best quality that
someone can have when they're a kid!
When I was 10 years old,

our teacher asked the class to draw a
picture of what we wanted to be when we

grew up. We had a worksheet with
this big box on it. And in it,

I drew a marine biologist, a woman who
was swimming with heaps of jellyfish,

and a dolphin. But I wanted
to be more than one thing.
So I flipped the paper over,

I drew another box and in
that I sketched a TV news

presenter, a woman standing
in front of the camera.

And now I have grown up
and I make science videos
and documentaries.

A lot of you know me as BrainCraft
lady or YouTube psychology host,

but actually my name is Vanessa
Hill. It's nice to meet you.

And I'm a behavioural scientist
and the creator of BrainCraft.

But what you might not
know is how I got here.

I kind of had to make my
own path. When I got to uni,

I still loved animals and nature.
So I started studying biology.

But over time I became more curious
about people and our brains and

behaviour. And trying to predict
how people act and behave,

that is somewhat of a mystery.
So I wanted to understand that.
I started teaching science in classrooms,

and I realised that there's so much
about your brain that isn't taught in

school. How to understand your personality
or procrastination or perception,

even how to deal with
anxiety and emotions,

or how to improve your
memory focus and even sleep.

More and more people were turning to the
internet to understand themselves and
their brain and their health.

So I started a YouTube channel to share
psychology and neuroscience research.

BrainCraft was born. But I
didn't know how to make videos.

So to learn, I watched
YouTube tutorials. One night,

I was coming home from a
friend's wedding on the train.

I checked my phone and I had
thousands of email notifications from

YouTube. My video on sleep
deprivation had gone viral.

In the time it took for
my friend to get married,

the video had gotten 500,000
views. At that point,

I decided to be a professional
YouTuber. BrainCraft

was picked up by PBS, which took
me from Australia to New York City.
Working in public media,

I saw that content has the
power to impact people's lives.

So I endeavoured to create science
content that pushes the boundaries of what
science media looks like.

And I created projects that could really
impact people's everyday wellbeing.

I was experimenting,
trying different things,

and I created the world's
first reality show about sleep.
The content everyone dreams about!

Where the contestants had to compete
to improve their sleep quantity

and quality. When the show came out,
I noticed a pattern in the comments.

The audience was like... Going
to bed early is too hard.

You have to be in Buddha not to use your
phone. I'm watching this at 3:00 AM.

I struggled to form good
habits. I can't change.

And I couldn't find any good
information to reply with.
We know that sleep is super important.

Behaviour change is a
whole field of science,

but even experts don't know the best
way for people to change their bedtime
behaviours. So I decided to study it.

Now I research how people can change their
evening habits to improve their sleep
quantity and quality,

which is super important for
our physical and mental health.

I must be one of the only researchers
who has formed their research questions
from YouTube comments.

My work has always explored the
space in between science and art,

but my mission is to use media to help
people positively change their behaviour.
And on my way here,

I didn't follow the traditional path
to being a scientist or even a video
host. And that's okay.

There are lots of different ways
to have an impact in science.

Everyone who's a scientist doesn't work
in a lab with test tubes or even swim

with dolphins. This is one
that kind of bizarre path,

of using science to change
the world. But it's my path!

It's my story. So what's
your story going to be?

I think we can, uh, we can
wrap now. Thanks for watching.
